summary: I want to thank the jonsas writers.
body:
I want to thank the jonsas writers.

The number of fics that have left after the end of the season are magnificent and have been able to give depth to the characters.

but

There’s something I do not understand, if the idea is to fix Jon’s behavior and character and pol!jon was real, I do not understand why he must be resentful with Sansa for telling about his true kinship, but at no time does he express that he feels sorry for the way of shit that treated Sansa(internal dialogue does not count, all the times that Sansa gave her support was quite vocal)

Why? why should Sansa be punished with his silence and should she wait for Jon to forgive her?

I understand that Jon was badly written but if you keep writing to Jon as who should receive everything from Sansa, but not giving anything to her we will continue to be dealing with the same Jon from S8 who did not respect Sansa.

I know Jon needs to recover and heal but Sansa needs it too.

Besides Sansa deserves to be QITN, she is the queen who never stopped fighting for the north, for their independence, she did not lose it or gave it away, she deserves to be queen, why I find it only matters if Sansa is queen but always lamenting that Jon is not her king?.

There are few writers I’ve seen doing this.

And yes I understand that we have to build the character and the romantic relationship, but There are two parts of this ship Jon and Sansa.

Sorry for the rant!! And my English!!

I love u

tags: book! sansa is special to me
i started being indifferent to her and loving arya and then the opposite happened
now she's my fave stark girl
also I stan (2) two queens in the north
question: Sansa for the character meme!
answer:
Ah so sorry for doing this so late. But here it goes for our Queen in The North.

SANSA STARK

  • Favorite Thing About Them: So ok, Sansa and Brienne of Tarth have MAJOR parallels (I so need Sansa and Brienne to meet and for her to be her knight ahhh). They both love songs, believe in the inherent goodness in the world via true knights and kind maidens, and they both have soft hearts. However, Brienne does not fit the mold of maiden fair and thus has to live through the knight persona. Sansa does fit the mold and but sees how her gold cage is poisonous. I think past me (circa 2012) says it best:

What makes her such an accessible and relatable character to other women, we too, like Sansa, are told to be pretty,smile and wait for a freaking prince to show up. We are degraded, beaten and have our dreams and personhood trampled on over and over again.Sansa realizes everything is a lie and begins to try to break free from the misogyny that has poisoned her. My favorite quote of hers: “what if I have girls? what if I only have girls?

However unlike Cersei who lives the same side of the coin, Sansa, much like Brienne, believes there’s some good in the world worth fighting for (Mr.Frodo). And thus as she plays the game, faces inner darkness, evil men, and an identity crisis, her kind heart remains. The kind heart is protected by steel (”from porcelain to ivory to”) much like Brienne has a physical armor. Much of Sansa’s arc, I feel, is reclaiming the inner wild woman within. Being the wolf she always was.

  • Least Favorite Thing: Not a character thing, but the collective fandom that has emerged behind her. Now the pendulum always swings. Back when I got into asoiaf in 2011, Sansa was underestimated and very criticized as a character for being ofc a typical teenage girl. Now she is very much beloved the iconic Queen of North, but there’s been a sort of mythos she is without criticism and that is not true. Sansa is superficial and manipulative to an extent, something she learns to survive. Also I love Sophie Turner as Sansa, but the Sansa past the rape plotline (DON’T GET ME STARTED ON THAT) becomes this emotionless figure. I understand this “steel” aspect to Sansa’s interpretation, but this hardening of her seems show-oriented and I don’t like it. She loves lemon cakes. She’s soft underneath. She plays the game and wears metaphorical armor. She’s never been cruel. She’s not Cersei.
  • Favorite Line: “I must be brave, like Robb” THIS KILLS ME FOR SOME REASON. Much like Brienne, Sansa associates bravery with knights and kings. A true knight, a true brave person like Robb. Like I said her arc, for me, is realizing she can be brave like Robb. Like a wolf. Because she is a wolf.
  • Random Headcanon: Sansa is pretty much bi. The whole Margaery thing, like come on.
  • Unpopular Opinion: Basically what I stated above. Don’t dig Sophie’s portrayal past certain seasons but to be fair that’s the writing and D&D so what can you do.
  • Song That Reminds me of Them: I think “State of Dreaming” from Marina and the Diamonds fits her pretty well.
  • Favorite Picture of Them: I don’t have one per say but I absolutely love this rendition of her which combines two of my favorite characters.

tags: only in passing but STILL let me live
summary: totally unrelated but YARA & SANSA TALKING ABOUT THEON POST-CANON
question: totally unrelated but YARA & SANSA TALKING ABOUT THEON POST-CANON
answer:
note: i’ve been avoiding this one for…. many reasons. i was going to incorporate it into another fic but i dunno if it’ll ever get written, so i figured i’ll just post it.

missing scene from 8x06.

Perhaps it’s luck that their paths intersect with Yara Greyjoy’s. Or maybe it is fate, with the urn Sansa carries still in her hands. 

Or maybe it is planned, unconsciously. 

Whatever it is, Sansa wordlessly nods at Arya and Bran; Arya pushes Bran ahead.

“Lady Greyjoy,” says Sansa, only her slightly shaking hands any indication of her nerves.

“Your Grace, Sansa Stark - Queen in the North.” There’s an edge to her voice, one Sansa expected. It’s a mixture of disgust, disappointment, and anger. But the loudest emotion is pain. “What does your Grace want?”

Sansa lets her gaze flicker downwards for a moment; but she is a queen now and will not be intimidated. With clear voice and strong heart, Sansa ignores the cracks inside. “I want to apologize for my sister’s earlier threat.”

“No you don’t,” says Yara, her smirk sarcastic and her voice bitter. “You only wished you could have made the threat yourself.”

It makes sense now; the confidence that masked anger and fear in Theon as a child. Sansa sees it again, now, with Yara. She bites back a smile. “That would not have been proper.”

Yara rolls her eyes. “Your brother killed my queen.” Her hands are tense, gripping her sword and axe tightly. “He killed my queen - but you. You killed my brother.”

A crack, somewhere within her chest; it’s numb now, not as painful as before, but it’s still there, an acidic fire threatening to burn her whole. “He saved my life.” The words are honey on her lips. “I loved him.”

Yara’s eyes narrow. “He spoke of you. Fondly. Said you saved him. You’re pretty, I will give him that. But no matter how good or pretty you are - you’re here and he’s not.”

“You’re right.” There’s nothing else to be said; Sansa knows it, is living it. It’s hard and painful and she tries not to dwell on it, not too much, because there’s too much to do and she’s suffered enough loss in her life. 

It scares her how easy it is to move on, now.

“I want you to have this.” Sansa gives the urn to his sister, his blood, his family. The scars on her heart pulse. “We had to burn him - but he deserves to be scattered at sea. This is half.”

“Where is the rest?”

“In the crypts of Winterfell.” Yara takes the urn from her, studying it, softly - it’s a rare moment where Sansa can see the affection and pain, before she hides it once more. Sansa stares at the urn - a light gray pot she had Gendry create for her, with the leaves of the Weirwood floating on water. “He was a Greyjoy by blood and by heart.”

Yara looks up at her but Sansa stares at her hands.

“He was your family and he died too far from the sea,” says Sansa, now locked onto Yara’s eyes - onto features so similar to his, a memory now, an echo. “But he was my family too.”

Yara watches her in silence, in thought. Finally: “Thank you.”

“I’m sorry.” It’s not enough, will never be enough, but it is all Sansa can say. She has no regrets; only hopes, wishes, dreams.

“Me too.”

Yara walks past to her own ship and Sansa does not bother looking back.

note: i’ve been avoiding this one for…. many reasons. i was going to incorporate it into another fic but i dunno if it’ll ever get written, so i figured i’ll just post it.

missing scene from 8x06.

Perhaps it’s luck that their paths intersect with Yara Greyjoy’s. Or maybe it is fate, with the urn Sansa carries still in her hands. 

Or maybe it is planned, unconsciously. 

Whatever it is, Sansa wordlessly nods at Arya and Bran; Arya pushes Bran ahead.

“Lady Greyjoy,” says Sansa, only her slightly shaking hands any indication of her nerves.

“Your Grace, Sansa Stark - Queen in the North.” There’s an edge to her voice, one Sansa expected. It’s a mixture of disgust, disappointment, and anger. But the loudest emotion is pain. “What does your Grace want?”

Sansa lets her gaze flicker downwards for a moment; but she is a queen now and will not be intimidated. With clear voice and strong heart, Sansa ignores the cracks inside. “I want to apologize for my sister’s earlier threat.”

“No you don’t,” says Yara, her smirk sarcastic and her voice bitter. “You only wished you could have made the threat yourself.”

It makes sense now; the confidence that masked anger and fear in Theon as a child. Sansa sees it again, now, with Yara. She bites back a smile. “That would not have been proper.”

Yara rolls her eyes. “Your brother killed my queen.” Her hands are tense, gripping her sword and axe tightly. “He killed my queen - but you. You killed my brother.”

A crack, somewhere within her chest; it’s numb now, not as painful as before, but it’s still there, an acidic fire threatening to burn her whole. “He saved my life.” The words are honey on her lips. “I loved him.”

Yara’s eyes narrow. “He spoke of you. Fondly. Said you saved him. You’re pretty, I will give him that. But no matter how good or pretty you are - you’re here and he’s not.”

“You’re right.” There’s nothing else to be said; Sansa knows it, is living it. It’s hard and painful and she tries not to dwell on it, not too much, because there’s too much to do and she’s suffered enough loss in her life. 

It scares her how easy it is to move on, now.

“I want you to have this.” Sansa gives the urn to his sister, his blood, his family. The scars on her heart pulse. “We had to burn him - but he deserves to be scattered at sea. This is half.”

“Where is the rest?”

“In the crypts of Winterfell.” Yara takes the urn from her, studying it, softly - it’s a rare moment where Sansa can see the affection and pain, before she hides it once more. Sansa stares at the urn - a light gray pot she had Gendry create for her, with the leaves of the Weirwood floating on water. “He was a Greyjoy by blood and by heart.”

Yara looks up at her but Sansa stares at her hands.

“He was your family and he died too far from the sea,” says Sansa, now locked onto Yara’s eyes - onto features so similar to his, a memory now, an echo. “But he was my family too.”

Yara watches her in silence, in thought. Finally: “Thank you.”

“I’m sorry.” It’s not enough, will never be enough, but it is all Sansa can say. She has no regrets; only hopes, wishes, dreams.

“Me too.”

Yara walks past to her own ship and Sansa does not bother looking back.
trail.content:

tags: she fought for her freedom and earned it and never ever had to give it up again
summary: Beyond glad that i never ever had to watch Sansa Stark truly kneel to another southern ruler, foreign queen, or leader of the...
body: Beyond glad that i never ever had to watch Sansa Stark truly kneel to another southern ruler, foreign queen, or leader of the north ever again. She got Winterfell back from the Boltons, they named her brother the King in the North, and she was free forever onward. Sansa Stark fought long and hard for her freedom and the freedom of her people, and they will never ever be forced to kneel to anyone other than the Queen in the North, whose name is Stark, chosen by her people, every again.

summary: People who say the writers made Sansa seem like a villain or cruel in s8 and that it’s sexist... umm sorry if you see a...
body: People who say the writers made Sansa seem like a villain or cruel in s8 and that it’s sexist… umm sorry if you see a confident, self-assured, intelligent, protective, rightly cautious but still diplomatic woman as an evil villain. Maybe you should take a look at why those traits make a woman seem villainous to you instead of crying out sexism at the show. The show has been sexist, but Sansa’s personality in s8 isn’t. So instead of talking about that so much, just because let’s be honest you just don’t like Sansa, why don’t you say something about the actual sexism on the show?

blog.description: my name is Merel and I'm a huge obsessive fangirl, which I express through vidding. I have made it my life's moto to defend Theon Greyjoy against all hate! american horror story (asylum) is my favourite series ever! and my dream is to go have a drink...

summary: Do you think show!Theon was in live with Sansa?
question: Do you think show!Theon was in live with Sansa?
answer: I don’t think so, they certainly had a close bond and I don’t think Theon would have said no to marrying her if he got the chance, but I don’t think that means they were in love. Being in love needs more than going through something traumatic together. Such an event can certainly bring people closer together, and it certainly did bring Theon and Sansa very close together and I really wanted them to have the chance to be close friends for a long time because there is no one else who can truely understand what they went through. So they certainly needed eachother to be able to not feel so alone in the world.
